video_title: $300 Ink?! The REAL Cost of the EufyMake UV Printer
comment_text:
Thanks for the review and updates. Super fast response to questions! Awesome.
Subscription software for functionality (credits...) is where I might have to think twice... At the forefront is "3D relief" or "depth printing" and that, from your brief answer, seems to be tied to a subscription that gives credits. Free tier has limited use, but based on their "you can make this much per day printing with this machine" the cost in credits should be calculated into this. 

Regardless, great product, wonderful price for entry. A bit shady in not being upfront and clear as to how much total running costs will be. I'd hoped companies would take note after the BambuLab "this is how we will operate going forward" backlash but looks like more *asterisk* stuff could be on the radar. 

Thanks for the updates again. See if you can get more information on the subscription tiers/specifics. If it's anything like Adobe (which I love, but costs a bit) then this is something to definitely factor into the cost of printing products as well as the ink.

Imagine a tradeshow/event with a line of 20+ clients and you run out of "credits" for generation...ChatGPT like tiers? Free - $20 - $200?....scary...

video_title: $300 Ink?! The REAL Cost of the EufyMake UV Printer
comment_text: Finally some that made a video about this. Remember that 3rd party inks can also cause clogging your print heads and might void your warranty. The key is, this is not a regular home printer, this is a professional UV Printer. The price that you should be charging your customers should be 3x or or higher depending on what you are printing and the method. I already have a UV Printer, a Roland flatbed, here is an example of what I charge for a name tags. We just completed an order of 90 name tags and we charge $10 each, out cost per name tag was around $1.50, we ganged the name tags on our flatbed. So a few jobs can definitely pay of this machine, just don't under sell your time and products.

video_title: $300 Ink?! The REAL Cost of the EufyMake UV Printer
comment_text: If people what to save money on ink they should open their images in Photoshop. Most people files will most likely be RGB. Convert the file to CYMK and then under color settings use GCR to removal color CMY used in the black. You can choose light, medium, heavy or max or custom. This will help remove ink which is really not needed in printing and save ink

comment_text:
Question....please help with my concern....... how can you assure us this product is ligit? Like that it's actually made and after we "pledge/order" we will recieve the "Reward/product" In July (when product is said to be ready)
I pulled this information offline....
• It is possible to back a Kickstarter project, receive the funds, and NOT receive your reward, potentially Losing Thousands of Dollars. Kickstarter is a crowdfunding platform where creators offer rewards for pledges, but backing a project doesn't guarantee reward fulfillment
• Delayed Fulfillment:
Delays are common in Kickstarter projects, and backers may have to wait months, or even years, to receive their rewards. 
• No Legal Recourse:
Kickstarter is not a legal marketplace, and there is no legal recourse for backers if a creator does not fulfill their pledges. 
Just sounds to good to be true.... and like a pretty big risk/Gamble.

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text:
Established companies like Anker, the owner of Eufy, should not be using Kickstarter as a funding platform. These corporations have ample financial resources to support their own projects, yet they turn to crowdfunding as a way to shift all risk onto consumers and backers. If their product fails—like their previous 3D printers—these companies remain unaffected, profiting from sold units while losing nothing on research and development.
What makes this situation particularly concerning is that working units of the product already exist, as multiple YouTubers have demonstrated in their reviews. So what, exactly, is being “Kickstarted”? The manufacturing process? This is not what Kickstarter was originally intended for. Unfortunately, more and more established and profitable companies continue to exploit the platform, using it as a shield to protect their investments rather than a genuine tool for innovation.
This unethical practice places all financial risk on backers, who are left vulnerable if the product fails. Meanwhile, content creators often enable this cycle by eagerly accepting free units and promoting them without scrutiny. If influencers refused to provide exposure to these companies without genuine accountability, failed launches could force corporations to rethink their approach and adhere to proper business practices.

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text:
I used a large format UV printer 11 years ago at the print shop I was Art Director for and it was AWESOME... EXCEPT..... The printer worked off of compressed air and oil for movements and we were constantly having breakdowns.
I'm hoping that a decade later and this thing being so small that a lot of the issues are no longer valid!

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: as a sticker printer who prints his own stickers id really me curious to explore what kind of stickers could be printed with this

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: only 5mm is too bad. It should be able to print on a full 360 degree model.

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: If the basic principles behind how this works aren't proprietary or patented, I'd like to see what other companies do with the concept. The brand trust for this machine is low, so maybe if someone like Elegoo does something with it, it might take off

comment_text: is the Ink dishwasher safe on the Mugs or Tumblers?

comment_text: This has amazing potential. Let’s see where that leads.

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: Eh... I received the H2D yesterday, I find that to be much better value... I know, different products... But if you're a maker, and owned neither, an 3D printer was the easy first choice... At the price, these will be a hard sell, even more so in USA....

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: cool tech.. but how does it compare to the cost printing/applying/sealing vinyl stickers (seeing that the most common use cases,  are realistically not going to be specialized 2.5D or odd material printing)?

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: Awesome products. With the wood wouldnt you just be able to paint the wood white first then print saving the ink?

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: Can this print tshirts?  The quality seems good and the 2.5D relief would be great and unique on shirts.  Not sure if it can and if ink would withstand wash dryer cycles.

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text:
Good idea but the risks from Anker and Eufy are far too great. 
More trustworthy companies will make better options soon enough.

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: How durable are the prints?  Can you scrape them with a knife?  Does it hold up to water or rubbing alcohol?

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: This is the first video I’ve seen of yours and the information is great. Thank you for that. But I hope you don’t take this the wrong way — the uptalk starts to become more noticeable.

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: Very cool!  I can see myself picking one up with all the available options, buying spare ink/cleaner, setting it up and playing with it for a week...then, never using it again (cause that's just the way my mind screws with me and my wallet!).  :)

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: Give this thing a dissolvable support material and a little more Z height and it can do full color 3D printing like a baby Stratasys J55.

comment_text: Awesome video! I’ve put a deposit down on an E1, can’t wait to get my hands on one. I really loved the Star Wars planet designs to used in the mug and the stickers. Are they for sale somewhere? Thanks for what you do. This was super helpful!

comment_text: looks pretty cool,  I really like hueforge on 3d printers. This seems like it might be the next level of that art and print form. excited to see what folks make when it hits. Just like inkjet printing, not so exicted about buying ink and its dries up or evaporates when not in use.
